newsitem.title: CANADA: Canada dollar closes firmer after bank rate cut.
newsitem.headline: Canada dollar closes firmer after bank rate cut.

text.p: The Canadian dollar ended stronger on Thursday after the Bank of Canada cut short-term interest rates, perhaps for the last time in this cycle.

Canada's central bank eased its key bank rate by 25 basis points to 4.25 percent after Germany's Bundesbank chopped short-term rates. The Bank of Canada released a statement which the market saw as a signal it will not lower rates further, said CIBC foreign exchange specialist Reid Farrill.
The Bank of Canada said the cumulative interest rate moves -- seven this year -- are "substantial" and can be expected to help the economy over the next year.

"Much of the market is surprised the dollar would strengthen on the day we have a rate cut," Farrill said. However, many investors who had parked their funds in U.S. currency rushed back to buy the Canadian dollar after the rate cut, he added.

In economic news, Statistics Canada reported stronger than expected retail sales for June, but said early signs pointed to a drop in July sales. Retail sales rose 0.6 percent to C$17.97 billion from C$17.86 billion in May.
The overnight range is from C$1.3650 to C$1.3710, Farrill said.
On the crosses, the Canada dollar rose to 1.0900 marks from Wednesday's close of 1.0784 marks and gained to 79.07 yen from roughly 78.89 yen.
